topic.title: All ZeroVerse sites are officially obsolete
topic.body:
I just had a minimal chat on IRC with Erkan Yƒ±lmaz, the guy behind all things ZeroVerse (e.g., ZeroVerse Mail and ID), and he told me that he is not using ZeroNet anymore. Around three months ago Erkan became very silent, but I hoped he had just gone to spend the summer in Turkey, or something. Instead it turns out he dropped out of ZeroNet. It's somewhat unfortunate, partly because some people were/are using his ZeroVerse ID+Mail services, partly because Erkan has squatted _a lot_ of zero*.bit domains, and of course also because Erkan had many good intentions for ZeroNet.
Well, we can't force people how to spend their energy, so instead of moaning the fact that Erkan has left ZeroNet, let's try to be practical. I, for one, will stop seeding all of Erkan's zites and stop using ZeroVerse Mail+ID. I suggest you guys do the same. Erkan might donate his lot of .bit domains to someone, but I'm not going to hold my breath. If he doesn't (and if he doesn't choose to renew the registration) they'll expire in about 84 days and will be up for the grabs.

/me hops off soapbox

Caveat: I'm not a ZeroNet developer.

As it stands, ZeroNet only works with IPv4 addresses and so it cannot currently work with a mesh network like hyperboria / cjdns that uses fc00::/8.

Perhaps [Zerotier](https://www.zerotier.com/#try_zerotier) could play a part? I have used it successfully for interconnecting my VPSes.  In the default setting it only allows 10 nodes if the node announcement is to be taken care of by ZeroTierOne, but the software is open source so it should be somewhat easy to set up controller nodes.

Best thing would be a fully decentralized and auto-discoverable mesh network, though. Are there any such beasts out there?

Last [Byzantium commit](https://github.com/Byzantium/Byzantium/commits/master) was 1¬Ω years ago, and their [last blog entry](http://project-byzantium.org/byzantium-v0-5b-hybrid/) is even older: it dates back to July 2013. He's dead, Jim. üòµ

12_14XxpXNGMLsyeQxikacrbQnAFXVyhN5Ngx.body:
At a first glance it looks good. However, I'm a bit sceptical ‚Äî but I hope someone can put me into shame‚Ä¶

Blockstack is the technology behind [Onename](https://onename.com/). Register a name there, and you get `yourname.id` as your identity/domain. Now, I'd forgotten that I had already registered an ID there, and some of the data ) entered at that time were obsolete and I updated the whole thing. This is now 36+ hours ago and the changes are still not reflected on the blockchain (i.e., if I `blockstack lookup ${MYID}.id` I still see the obsolete data).

As it stands, I cannot know whether delay is caused by onename.com or the blockstack technology, but we have all seen the outrageous time it takes to have a transaction included in the blockchain these days, so my suggestion is that blockstack/onename.com should have chosen another blockchain to ‚Äòhost‚Äô their data.

I hope someone has more info about the inner workings of this technology.

> http://blog.namecoin.org/post/130158040415/onenames-blockstore-is-much-less-secure-than

A long and interesting read. Thanks, Erkan.
And then there's [EmerCoin](http://emercoin.com/EMCDNS_and_NVS), that seems to be built for such things. However, Microsoft seems to be deeply involved in that coin ‚Äî that's a bad sign.

6_178NSuZP2hH2vHhNX6vsHceh5sjPkDrLiH.body:
In its current incarnation IPFS is primarily aimed at static content. And if you actually try it, you will find that IPFS is far slower at fetching files from its peers than Zeronet are. Also, its naming is not meant for humans (e.g., `/ipns/QmYsCYvMXHNtNwjnXu94UCMssaGE3iUd7AAwG5iKdMZ2vP/twtxt.txt`) and at the moment you can only have one name per peer, AFAIK.

That said, IPFS is an amazing piece of work and I look forward to see where it will go. I can also imagine that IPFS and Zeronet at some point will be able to complement each other so that IPFS could be used as sort of a backend for larger files to be served on Zeronet.
See also the thread [Large file sharing with IPFS is not anonymous](/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:5_1GCMDNMgJHvZJfdbD9ygDmpBdnVAobdJYg/).

> [nofishes](#comment_5_12yaKkoqVKBUi66uB5pYXamWguKFaWdDnx): like this { "zeronet" : { "" : "zeronet address"} }

I have never done this from the QT wallet, I always use the `namecoin-cli` thing, but I guess we're talking about the same thing.

When you registered your domain you made a `name_firstupdate "name" "rand" "tx" "value"`, where `value` was the JSON for your domain. Now you just have to do a `name_update "name" "value"`, where `value` could be the same or some other JSON.

Remember that `name` is not `mydomain.bit` but `d/mydomain`.
